change.p: Created file for the first time.

div.head: Question 24
Whether contraries are able to be coextended in the same subject?
div.p: Whether contraries are able to be coextended in the same subject?

That they are, some contrary is able to be remitted. But one thing is remitted unless account of the intension of another. The minor is proved through the Commentator 9 Physics, in comment 45, where he says that a decrease in anything is on account of the mixture of its contrary, and the same in comment 19 of the same book, and in many other places of the same book. And thus in every mixed thing there is one element predominating to which the form is attributed and another which is predominated, just as is clear in book 10 of the metaphysics, in comment 23 and in book 1 de caelo, in comment 7, where it is frequently held that every mixed thing dies according to the mode of the dominating element, therefore in every mixed thing there are contrary elements and two contrary qualities because unless the qualities will be contrary there, the contrary elements will not be there. the consequent is false.

It should be responded to this that the remission through admixture is able to be understood in two ways. Either that its contrary coextends with it in the same matter and this is impossible. Or that the mixture is of a contrary agent into a passive, and thus I concede that every that becomes less, becomes less through the admixture of its contrary through which the response to the first is clear.

To the second it is said that no element is a qualitative part of the mixed, but only qualitative, and any element thus remitted through the mixture of its contrary is a mixed body, and therefore some part of the mixed is mixed. Whence when something is composed from two transitory contraries according to itself alone, then some part is remitted and mixed.
To the understanding of Aristotle, it is not possible that something mixed is essentially composed from contraries.
And to the Commentator in comment 23, I say that he understands through the impossible what is difficult and Galen understood through the possible what is easy, etc.
